data.output_data: [{"name": null, "message_id": "4efdd748b1834bed803358685e7b6216", "timestamp": 1755002158430910000, "content": "{\"query\": \"elevation range eastern Colorado orogeny\", \"answer\": null, \"results\": [{\"title\": \"List of mountain ranges of Colorado - Wikipedia\", \"url\": \"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_mountain_ranges_of_Colorado\", \"content\": \"| La Garita Mountains | | Phoenix Peak \\\"Phoenix Peak (Colorado)\\\")-94)-95)-96) | 13,902\\u00a0ft 4237\\u00a0m | 1,495\\u00a0ft 456\\u00a0m | 3.03\\u00a0mi 4.87\\u00a0km | | Southern San Juan Mountains | | Summit Peak | 13,307\\u00a0ft 4056\\u00a0m | 2,760\\u00a0ft 841\\u00a0m | 39.6\\u00a0mi 63.7\\u00a0km | | South Williams Fork Mountains | Ptarmigan Peak \\\"Ptarmigan Peak (Colorado)\\\")-162)-163)-164) | 12,504\\u00a0ft 3811\\u00a0m | 721\\u00a0ft 220\\u00a0m | 4.3\\u00a0mi 6.92\\u00a0km | | Elk Mountains \\\"Elk Mountains (Colorado)\\\")-182) |  | | Castle Peak \\\"Castle Peak (Colorado)\\\")-183)-184)-185)-186) | 14,279\\u00a0ft 4352\\u00a0m | 2,365\\u00a0ft 721\\u00a0m | 20.9\\u00a0mi 33.6\\u00a0km |\", \"score\": 0.98586}, {\"title\": \"Colorado orogeny - Wikipedia\", \"url\": \"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colorado_orogeny\", \"content\": \"The Colorado orogen, formerly called the Colorado province \\\"Province (geology)\\\"), is a >500-km-wide belt of oceanic arc rock (1.78\\u20131.65 Ga) that extends southward into New Mexico and composes a major part of the Proterozoic provinces of southwestern United States. The boundary between the Colorado orogeny and the Wyoming craton is the Cheyenne belt, a 5-km-wide mylonitic shear zone that verges \\\"Vergence (geology)\\\") northward. The Paleoproterozoic volcanic and sedimentary rocks that resulted from the Colorado orogeny underwent metamorphism followed by plastic folding \\\"Fold (geology)\\\") under moderate pressure and temperature (PT) conditions (temperature about 500 \\u00b0C and pressures in excess of 1.2 GPa \\\"Pascal (unit)\\\")). Farther south, more distant from the Cheyenne belt, fold patterns differ materially from those in the northernmost part of the Colorado orogeny.\", \"score\": 0.98559}, {\"title\": \"Geology of Rocky Mountain National Park\", \"url\": \"https://www.usgs.gov/geology-and-ecology-of-national-parks/geology-rocky-mountain-national-park\", \"content\": \"Geology of Rocky Mountain National Park | U.S. Geological Survey Rocky Mountain Region Geology of Rocky Mountain National Park The creation of Rocky Mountain National Park has been over a billion years in the making! Glaciation is one of the strongest erosional forces on the planet and is responsible for shaping Rocky Mountain National Park as it is today. There are no more valley glaciers in Rocky Mountain National park today but they were abundant about 15,000 years ago. The only remaining type of glacier in Rocky Mountain National Park is a cirque glacier, which is a small glacier (sometimes the remnant of an old valley glacier) that occupies the bowl shape within a small valley.\", \"score\": 0.98439}, {\"title\": \"Topographic Features - Colorado Climate Center\", \"url\": \"https://climate.colostate.edu/climate_long.html\", \"content\": \"Of particular importance to the climate are Colorado's interior continental location in the middle latitudes, the high elevation of the entire region, and the mountains and ranges extending north and south approximately through the middle of the State. With elevations ranging from below 7,000 feet in the lower mountain valleys to more than 14,000 feet on the highest peaks, all aspects of the climate are affected: temperature, humidity, precipitation and, of course, wind. Temperatures can drop below zero F in all areas of western Colorado, but the valleys of west central and southwest Colorado receive abundant sunshine and the winter climate is not harsh. In a year of near-normal snow accumulations in the mountains and normal spring temperatures, river stages become high, but there is no general flooding.\", \"score\": 0.98272}, {\"title\": \"The Evolution of the Colorado Plateau and Colorado River\", \"url\": \"https://glencanyon.org/the-evolution-of-the-colorado-plateau-and-colorado-river/\", \"content\": \"During its course, the river cuts through nearly 2 billion years of earth\\u2019s geologic history, representing three distinct geologic provinces (the Rocky Mountain, Colorado Plateau, and Basin and Range Provinces). As the Colorado River emerges from the Rocky Mountain Province it flows southwest from its headwaters and enters a different geologic area, the Colorado Plateau Province. Uplift of the Rocky Mountains created by the Laramide Orogeny, 70 to 40 million years ago, established an elevated platform for canyons to form (remember a river needs an elevation difference so water can flow from high to low). There is, however, general agreement by most researchers that the Colorado River, by at least 6 million years ago, was a river that flowed from the Rocky Mountains to the present Pacific Ocean.\", \"score\": 0.97695}]}", "refusal": null, "annotations": null, "audio": null, "role": "tool", "tool_call_id": "call_PJoE3wXCsIynJH87e73QanMD", "tools": null, "function_call": null, "tool_calls": null, "is_streaming": false}]

The boundary between the Colorado orogeny and the Wyoming craton is the Cheyenne belt, a 5-km-wide mylonitic shear zone that verges \\\"Vergence (geology)\\\") northward. The Paleoproterozoic volcanic and sedimentary rocks that resulted from the Colorado orogeny underwent metamorphism followed by plastic folding \\\"Fold (geology)\\\") under moderate pressure and temperature (PT) conditions (temperature about 500 \\u00b0C and pressures in excess of 1.2 GPa \\\"Pascal (unit)\\\")). Farther south, more distant from the Cheyenne belt, fold patterns differ materially from those in the northernmost part of the Colorado orogeny.\", \"score\": 0.98559}, {\"title\": \"Geology of Rocky Mountain National Park\", \"url\": \"https://www.usgs.gov/geology-and-ecology-of-national-parks/geology-rocky-mountain-national-park\", \"content\": \"Geology of Rocky Mountain National Park | U.S. Geological Survey Rocky Mountain Region Geology of Rocky Mountain National Park The creation of Rocky Mountain National Park has been over a billion years in the making! Glaciation is one of the strongest erosional forces on the planet and is responsible for shaping Rocky Mountain National Park as it is today. There are no more valley glaciers in Rocky Mountain National park today but they were abundant about 15,000 years ago. The only remaining type of glacier in Rocky Mountain National Park is a cirque glacier, which is a small glacier (sometimes the remnant of an old valley glacier) that occupies the bowl shape within a small valley.\", \"score\": 0.98439}, {\"title\": \"Topographic Features - Colorado Climate Center\", \"url\": \"https://climate.colostate.edu/climate_long.html\", \"content\": \"Of particular importance to the climate are Colorado's interior continental location in the middle latitudes, the high elevation of the entire region, and the mountains and ranges extending north and south approximately through the middle of the State. With elevations ranging from below 7,000 feet in the lower mountain valleys to more than 14,000 feet on the highest peaks, all aspects of the climate are affected: temperature, humidity, precipitation and, of course, wind. Temperatures can drop below zero F in all areas of western Colorado, but the valleys of west central and southwest Colorado receive abundant sunshine and the winter climate is not harsh. In a year of near-normal snow accumulations in the mountains and normal spring temperatures, river stages become high, but there is no general flooding.\", \"score\": 0.98272}, {\"title\": \"The Evolution of the Colorado Plateau and Colorado River\", \"url\": \"https://glencanyon.org/the-evolution-of-the-colorado-plateau-and-colorado-river/\", \"content\": \"During its course, the river cuts through nearly 2 billion years of earth\\u2019s geologic history, representing three distinct geologic provinces (the Rocky Mountain, Colorado Plateau, and Basin and Range Provinces). As the Colorado River emerges from the Rocky Mountain Province it flows southwest from its headwaters and enters a different geologic area, the Colorado Plateau Province. Uplift of the Rocky Mountains created by the Laramide Orogeny, 70 to 40 million years ago, established an elevated platform for canyons to form (remember a river needs an elevation difference so water can flow from high to low). There is, however, general agreement by most researchers that the Colorado River, by at least 6 million years ago, was a river that flowed from the Rocky Mountains to the present Pacific Ocean.\", \"score\": 0.97695}]}", "refusal": null, "annotations": null, "audio": null, "role": "tool", "tool_call_id": "call_PJoE3wXCsIynJH87e73QanMD", "tools": null, "function_call": null, "tool_calls": null, "is_streaming": false}]
